case_vignette: A 4-year-old girl presents to the office with her parents who are concerned about their daughter and slow, progressive changes in her behavior. The girl was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is up to date on all vaccines and was meeting all developmental milestones until about 2 years ago. At one point she had a vocabulary of several words and now she verbalizes in grunts. She also flaps her hands in a repeated motion and has difficulty walking. Her parents have tried several home therapies to improve their daughter's symptoms including restricted diets, hydrotherapy, and a variety of nutritional supplements. The vital signs include: heart rate 90/min, respiratory rate 22/min, blood pressure 110/65 mm Hg, and temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F). On physical exam, she is well nourished and stares absently out the window. Her heart has a regular rate and rhythm and her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. She has mild scoliosis.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have started speaking in grunts instead of words, I flap my hands a lot, and I'm having trouble walking.
How old are you?
I am 4 years old.
Are you a boy or a girl?
I am a girl.
When did you first start experiencing these symptoms?
I started having these symptoms about 2 years ago.
Have your symptoms been getting progressively worse, staying the same, or improving over time?
My symptoms have been getting progressively worse over time.
Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications?
No, I don't have any other medical conditions and I'm not taking any medications.
Do you have any problems with eating or swallowing?
No, I don't have any problems with eating or swallowing.
Have you experienced any seizures or changes in consciousness?
No, I haven't experienced any seizures or changes in consciousness.
Is there any family history of neurological disorders?
The case vignette doesn't provide information about my family's medical history.
Have you had any recent infections or fevers?
I haven't had any recent infections or fevers.
Have you had any issues with your hearing or vision?
No, I haven't had issues with my hearing or vision.
Has a doctor previously evaluated you for developmental disorders or autism?
The case vignette does not specify if I have been evaluated for developmental disorders or autism by a doctor.
**Final Diagnosis:** Rett syndrome

I've been having trouble speaking with just grunting, I flap my hands a lot, and I'm having difficulty walking.

I'm 4 years old.

I've been making repeated hand-flapping motions, having trouble walking, and now I only speak in grunts instead of words.
How old are you and what is your sex?
I'm a 4-year-old girl.
